required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of a Diabetes Data Management System
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of a Diabetes Data Management System In a Clinical Setting

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate a diabetes data management program in the hands of potential users, both health care professionals and lay users.

detailed_description.textblock: Diabetes data management programs analyze blood glucose results downloaded from glucose meters to assist health care professionals or lay users manage their diabetes. During the study, subjects download meters, generate and print reports, evaluate the program's ease of use, and verify that they understand the program output.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants That Rated 80% of Tasks as Very Simple, Simple, or Neither Simple Nor Difficult (Ease of Use of the Software Program)
primary_outcome.description: After completing each task, subjects rated the ease of performing each task on a scale of 1 to 5. Very Simple Simple Neither simple nor difficult Difficult Very Difficult Outcome measure was the number of participants that rated 80% of tasks as 1,2, or 3.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Rated as <= 3 (Success in Using the Program)
primary_outcome.description: Subjects were rated by study staff as to their success at performing basic tasks. The rating scale was: successful successful after being referred to user instructions success with assistance (similar to a customer call) unsuccessful 5 = software problem Outcome measure was the number of participants rated as <= 3.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants That Could Answer at Least 85% of the Comprehension Questions Correctly (Comprehension of the Program Reports)
primary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked thirty questions throughout the evaluation to test whether they understood the data displays, graphs and features of the software. Outcome measure was the number of participants that could answer at least 85% of the comprehension questions correctly.

arm_group.arm_group_label: health care professionals and lay users
arm_group.description: h= 8 health care professionals p= 43 lay users

study_pop.textblock: Lay users males or females and health care professionals.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Health Care Professionals:
1. Must have experience using diabetes data management software in the medical office such as downloading meters, reviewing reports (computer screen or printouts), or assisting in patients' diabetes disease management using software.
2. May include: endocrinologists, primary care physicians, nurse educators, or other medical staff involved in downloading meters or interpreting the data output.
- Lay users must:
1. Be at least 18 years of age.
2. Have diabetes (or be the parent or legal guardian of a child with diabetes) and have been testing blood sugar at home at least twice daily for one month or more.
3. Be able to speak, read and understand English.
4. Currently using diabetes management software at home or be familiar with diabetes management software. At least 75% of subjects must have been using software for at least one month.
5. Have experience using PC programs or browsing the internet.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Persons working for a competitive medical device company.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The null and alternative hypotheses for these tests will have the form: Ho: Pr{Success} < Po vs. Ha: Pr{Success} ≥ Po. Critical values for numbers of successes were computed to give approximately a 90% chance of rejecting Ho in favor of the alternative (non-inferiority) if the true probability of success is at least Po. For Po = 80%, with n=51, critical number is 38. With this critical value and sample size, the power to reject Ho is approximately 87.43%.

outcome.title: Number of Participants Rated as <= 3 (Success in Using the Program)
outcome.description: Subjects were rated by study staff as to their success at performing basic tasks. The rating scale was: successful successful after being referred to user instructions success with assistance (similar to a customer call) unsuccessful 5 = software problem Outcome measure was the number of participants rated as <= 3.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The null and alternative hypotheses for these tests will have the form: Ho: Pr{Success} < Po vs. Ha: Pr{Success} ≥ Po. Critical values for numbers of successes were computed to give approximately a 90% chance of rejecting Ho in favor of the alternative (non-inferiority) if the true probability of success is at least Po. For Po = 95%, with n=51, critical number is 47. With this critical value and sample size, the power to reject Ho is approximately 88.96%.

outcome.description: Subjects were asked thirty questions throughout the evaluation to test whether they understood the data displays, graphs and features of the software. Outcome measure was the number of participants that could answer at least 85% of the comprehension questions correctly.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The null and alternative hypotheses for these tests will have the form: Ho: Pr{Success} < Po vs. Ha: Pr{Success} ≥ Po. Critical values for numbers of successes were computed to give approximately a 90% chance of rejecting Ho in favor of the alternative (non-inferiority) if the true probability of success is at least Po. For Po = 90%, with n=51, critical number is 43. With this critical value and sample size, the power to reject Ho is approximately 93.57%.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
